update.description:
Fix issue #30.

* [Gazebo's grid](https://bitbucket.org/osrf/gazebo/src/6f357235d464f26f5ffc61f90e17e67f788703f5/gazebo/rendering/Scene.cc?at=default#cl-2695) is composed of 2 grids:

1.  20x20, step = 1, color (0.3,0.3,0.3,0.5)
2. 4x4, step = 5, color (0.8, 0.8, 0.8, 0.5)

* Gzweb uses Three.js's [GridHelper](https://github.com/mrdoob/three.js/blob/master/src/extras/helpers/GridHelper.js), which is a combination of 2 grids by default, but one of them is just a cross following X and Y. [This](#!/osrf/gzweb/pull-request/18/fixing-scene-colors/diff#Lgz3d/src/gzscene.jsT390) changes the default colors to those of Gazebo's.

* Also changes Gzweb's rendered [ClearColor](#!/osrf/gzweb/pull-request/18/fixing-scene-colors/diff#Lgz3d/src/gzscene.jsT22) to `#b2b2b2` (178,178,178) to match Gazebo's background color.

* The floor plane (Gazebo's ambient) is receiving the color Gazebo/Grey, so I didn't want to change it.

* [Gazebo's ambient light](https://bitbucket.org/osrf/gazebo/src/6f357235d464f26f5ffc61f90e17e67f788703f5/gazebo/rendering/Scene.cc?at=default#cl-270) is (0.1, 0.1, 0.1, 0.1). Three.js's ambient light does not take an alpha value, so setting it to `#1a1a1a` (0.1, 0.1, 0.1) illuminates too much. I chose [a value](#!/osrf/gzweb/pull-request/18/fixing-scene-colors/diff#Lgz3d/src/gzscene.jsT28) so that after illumination, the floor gets the same color on both Gazebo and Gzweb: `#9b9b9b`.

* After illumination, the grids have slightly different colors.

* [These screenshots](https://www.dropbox.com/s/mt8t8faf2syf6wd/gzwebColors.png) show the results.

If a 4x4 lighter grid like Gazebo's is preferred, we will have to reconstruct Three.js's GridHelper from scratch.

I'm not sure if the change is ambient light has a wanted effect on different models put in the scene.
update.title: Fixing scene colors

content.raw: The screenshots look good. I mainly chimed in to point out where to look in the gazebo codebase for the grid colors.
content.html: The screenshots look good. I mainly chimed in to point out where to look in the gazebo codebase for the grid colors.

content.raw: @scpeters, I now have the same colors as the one in her [screenshot](https://www.dropbox.com/s/mt8t8faf2syf6wd/gzwebColors.png). Looks ok to you?
content.html: @scpeters, I now have the same colors as the one in her screenshot. Looks ok to you?

the other machine works fine.

content.html:
the other machine works fine.

I just did a clean build and now I have the same colors as you, sorry for the noise!

content.raw: the inconsistency of the ground plane color is strange to me. I am going to try on a different machine

content.raw: Maybe with `this.ambient = new THREE.AmbientLight( 0x1a1a1a );` it looks just right for you? For me it's too dark.
content.html: Maybe with this.ambient = new THREE.AmbientLight( 0x1a1a1a ); it looks just right for you? For me it's too dark.

content.raw:
I am getting something like [this](https://www.dropbox.com/s/oo42v36mnfo1gnf/gzweb_new_colors.png).

The grid colors look good!

* [Gazebo's ambient light](https://bitbucket.org/osrf/gazebo/src/6f357235d464f26f5ffc61f90e17e67f788703f5/gazebo/rendering/Scene.cc?at=default#cl-270) is (0.1, 0.1, 0.1, 0.1). Three.js's ambient light does not take an alpha value, so setting it to #1a1a1a (0.1, 0.1, 0.1) illuminates too much. I chose [a value](https://bitbucket.org/chapulina/gzweb/pull-request/new#Lgz3d/src/gzscene.jsT28) so that after illumination, the floor gets the same color on both Gazebo and Gzweb: #9b9b9b.

* After illumination, the grids have slightly different colors.

* [These screenshots](https://www.dropbox.com/s/mt8t8faf2syf6wd/gzwebColors.png) show the results.
update.title: Fixing scene colors
